title: DT Swiss F 132 Gravel Fork
content:
Component manufacturer DT Swiss just unveiled its all-new F 132 gravel suspension fork this morning with some interesting features and some puzzling ones. Let’s check it out below…

DT Swiss F 132 Quick Hits

  • Weight: 1340 g (without Remote Lever, Cabel, Axle, RWS Plug-In Lever)
  • Travel: 40 mm of travel with an air spring that can be adjusted with a shock pump.
  • Axle to crown: 435 mm
  • Steerer: 330 mm
  • Max tire size: 50 mm
  • Pushcontrol: An ergonomic lever can be operated from any hand position on the drop bar, so open and lock mode changes can be made quickly and easily.
  • Plaingain & Lineair SL: The Lineair SL spring cartridge with a positive and negative air chamber, as well as the Plaingain damping cartridge, enables a real capacity to absorb shocks while being as light as possible.
  • Integrated cables: The F 132 ONE is no exception and allows for the complete internal routing.
  • Cargo Cage Adapters: The gravel bike adventure can be brought even further by fixing bags on the bike.

The DT Swiss F 132 looks sleek and elegant when paired with a modern gravel bike. Its integrated cables offer unparalleled levels of “cleanness,” and the positive and negative air chambers, as well as a damper, mean you’ll be able to tune this fork to match your riding style and conditions. Well done across the board here, but we have notes…

A Design Feature We Dig

The cargo cage adapters are genius, and it’s been something we’ve been asking manufacturers why they haven’t implemented something similar in the past. DT Swiss’ design of the cargo cages blends seamlessly with the fork when installed.

A Design Feature We Question

The Pushcontrol remote lock-out might seem like a good idea at first glance, but in reality, it’s taking up the real estate for a dropper trigger on a drop bar bike. When you descend in the drops and are running a dropper, being able to actuate it from this exact location is crucial. In our opinion, the need for a suspension fork ought to be complemented by a dropper post to achieve the full range of motion of body english on the descent. Perhaps there could be a Pushcontrol for the right side of the handlebar instead? This seems like an oversight.

Toward Drop-Bar Mountain Bikes

As gravel bikes eke into drop bar mountain bike terrain, there is but one step left in this evolution: boost spacing. We’re almost there with forks like the F 132 and dropper posts. The recent trend of gravel pros realizing the benefits of 2.3″ tires also points in this direction.

What do you think?

Check out more at DT Swiss.

The post DT Swiss F 132 Gravel Fork appeared first on The Radavist.
author: John Watson
